Graphical abstract In this work, CuOx/Chabazite(CHA, SSZ-13, SAPO-34 etc) catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method for ammonia selective catalytic oxidation. CuOx/H-SSZ-13 exhibited superior NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity compared with CuOx/H-SAPO-34 below 300 °C under both dry and wet conditions. The better low-temperature activity of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 was due to its greater NH3 adsorption and activation capacity. DRIFTS results showed that –NH2 and –NH radicals can be observed on the spectra of CuOx/H-SSZ-13, whereas, only –NH2 radicals were obtained on the spectra of CuOx/H-SAPO-34. CuOx (including CuO and Cu2O) were determined as active phases of the catalysts using XRD and XPS results. The catalytic performance of CuOx/CHA catalysts was reversibly suppressed in the presence of H2O and SO2 regarding the formation of NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 on the catalysts surface. Furthermore, CuSO4 was also formed and could not decompose until 700 °C. However, it showed less influence on the catalytic performance. Keywords NH3-SCO Selective catalytic oxidation Ammonia CHA Copper 1 Introduction As a cross-medium complex pollutant, ammonia (NH3) is harmful to human health and natural environment [1,2]. In modern industrial activities, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology is the widely used method to eliminate NOx from the stationary source. However, in the NH3-SCR systems, the stoichiometric (NH3/NOx ≈ 0.9) or even excessive urea is provided to meet NOx reduction targets, which mean unreacted ammonia would be discharged directly into the atmosphere. Similarly, for vehicles with a post-treatment system, ammonia may slip if the dosing device excessively adds reductant to the exhaust flowing through the exhaust system. In recent years, ultra-low emission standards are proposed in China, which has stricter limits on the emission NOx concentration. There is a greater chance that slipping ammonia become a considerable problem. Therefore, it is necessary to control the slipping ammonia. Adsorption, catalytic decomposition, catalytic oxidation and biofiltration [3–6] are some of the widely studied and used ammonia elimination technologies. As one of the most promising technologies, selective catalytic oxidation technology (SCO) can be used behind the NH3-SCR system to oxidize the slipping ammonia to nitrogen. SCO catalysts are the core of this technology. In the catalytic oxidation process, nitrogen and three other nitrogen oxides (NOx) will generate at different rates. The most desirable pathway is to convert ammonia into harmless nitrogen and water. Other side reactions should be avoided because of their secondary pollution. Therefore, both high NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity are critical. Besides, the low-temperature activity of SCO catalysts should be effective to avoid additional heating. So far, many works have focused on developing effective catalytic materials to meet these challenges. The noble metals including Pt, Ag and Pd have applied as SCO catalysts due to their excellent low-temperature catalytic activity. Unfortunately, high cost and significant by-products formation limited their applications [7,8]. Hereafter, cheap and readily available transition metals such as Fe, Ni, Co and Mn have been widely regarded as potential catalysts for NH3-SCO technology. Nevertheless, relatively low catalytic activity prevented their widespread applications [9,10]. In such cases, copper-based catalysts attracted much attention due to their optimum operation window for high activity, selectivity and stability. Compared to other transition metal catalysts, copper-based catalysts own stronger redox properties to oxidize ammonia at low temperatures. Large numbers of copper-based catalysts such as Cu/Al2O3, Pt/Cu/Al2O3, and CuFe2O4 were investigated [11–14]. Gang et al. [15] reported that Cu/Al2O3 catalysts performed good SCO activity with full NH3 conversion temperature at 350 °C and 90% N2 selectivity and 10 wt.% copper was considered to be the most appropriate loadings. In addition to the redox properties, another critical factor that affects the activity in NH3-SCO reactions is surface acidity. Many works utilized alumina and zeolites as supports because of their abundant acidity, which were good for capturing ammonia to the active phases existed on the catalysts surface. Zeolites supported catalysts were reported to show slightly better SCO activity compared to alumina supported catalysts under the same preparation conditions [16]. Recent developments in copper-exchanged small-pore chabazite zeolites (Cu-SAPO-34 and Cu-SSZ-13) drew much attention in SCR reactions for their excellent catalytic performance and strong resistance to hydrothermal aging [17,18]. Simultaneously, catalysts prepared with silico aluminophosphate supports also had a good catalytic activity for ammonia oxidation [19,20]. In addition to these influencing factors, previously reported SCO catalysts were very sensitive to SO2 because of deactivation [21,22]. Therefore, it is necessary to comprehend the influence of SO2 on the SCO catalytic activity and its poisoning mechanism. Different supports would lead to different catalytic performance. In this work, the copper-based catalysts prepared with different CHA supports (H-SAPO-34 and H-SSZ-13) were studied for NH3-SCO reactions. The results indicated that CuOx/H-SSZ-13 exhibited much higher NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity than that of CuOx/H-SAPO-34 below 300 °C in the dry and wet atmosphere. A series of appropriate methods were used to investigate structure-activity relationship on the CuOx/CHA catalysts. In addition, the influence of SO2 was investigated, and it was found that the deactivation of SO2 poisoning was mostly reversible on the CuOx/CHA catalysts. Our findings suggest that CuOx/CHA, especially CuOx/H-SSZ-13, are the promising potential SCO catalysts in the practical application of ammonia oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation CuOx/CHA catalysts were prepared by the conventional wet impregnation method. CHA structure zeolites including H-SSZ-13 (Si:Al = 7:1) and H-SAPO-34 (Si:Al:P = 1:4:4) were used as the supports. A certain amount of pre-calcined supports and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O were added into deionized water with thoroughly stirring for 30 min at room temperature. After impregnation, the rotary evaporator was used to remove excessive water at 60 °C. The samples were dried overnight at 100 °C and calcined in the air at 400 °C for 6 h. The loadings of copper were both 10 wt.% (the weight ratio of copper oxide to the supports). In order to examine the stability of catalysts, both CuOx/CHA catalysts were hydrothermally treated at 700 °C for 10 h in air flow containing 10 vol.% H2O. The hydrothermal aged catalysts were labeled as CuOx/CHA-HT. As a comparison, Cu-CHA catalysts were synthesized by a two-step ion-exchange method. The solid supports were added to NH4NO3(1 M) for 4 h under stirring and then washed by deionized water. After repeating this process three times, the samples were dried overnight to obtain NH4-CHA samples. The NH4-CHA samples were added to Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O solution (0.05 M) and stirred at 70 °C for 4 h. Finally, the samples were centrifuged and calcined at 400 °C for 6 h. Commercial 1 wt. % Pt/Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar) was dried and calcined at the same calcination temperature. All the samples were pressed using 10 t pressure and sieved into 40 ˜ 60 meshes before testing. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The scanning electron microscopy images (SEM) of samples with X-ray energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) were obtained by a GEMINISEM 500 scanning electron microscope. The elemental contents were acquired using inductive coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by the Bruker D/max-2200 Diffractometer. The scanning range was from 5 to 50° at a scanning rate of 5°·min−1. N2 adsorption/desorption experiments were performed on the Belsorp Max II instrument. Before analysis, the samples were outgassed in vacuum at 300 °C for 4 h. The specific surface areas of the samples were evaluated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) multiple point method. Solid-state 27Al, 28Si and 31P MAS NMR experiments were conducted on a JNM-ECZ600R spectrometer and the spinning rate was 12 kHz. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) experiments were carried out on the Escalab 250Xi equipment using Al Kα radiation (1486.7 eV). The binding energy value of carbon deposit C1s at 284.8 eV was used to correct the binding energy. Temperature programmed desorption with NH3 (NH3-TPD) experiments were made in a fixed-bed reactor equipped with an IR spectrometer (Multi Gas 2030 HS, MKS). Before tests, the samples (100 mg) were pretreated at 300 °C in N2 atmosphere (200 mL·min−1) for 1 h and followed by cooling down to 100 °C. NH3 (500 ppm) was introduced until saturation. Then the samples were purged with N2 flow to sweep the exceeding NH3 physically adsorbed on the sample until a constant baseline level reached. The desorption results were obtained in N2 at 100 ˜ 750 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. Temperature programmed desorption with SO2 (SO2-TPD) experiments were carried out in a fixed-bed reactor loaded with a FTIR Gas Analyzer (Gasmet DX 4000). The samples (100 mg) were firstly heated with N2 (200 mL·min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to 50 °C. The samples were saturated with SO2/N2 and purged in N2 flow to remove absorbed species. For analysis, the samples were heated to 900 °C at the temperature rate of 10 °C·min−1 in N2 flow for desorption. Temperature programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) experiments were measured in the AutoChem II 2920 Micromeritics Analyzer using 5 vol. % H2/Ar as a reductant. Samples (100 mg) were firstly pretreated in Ar atmosphere (50 mL·min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h and cooled down to 50 °C at the same flow rate. The temperature increased from 50 to 950 °C at a constant rate of 10 °C·min−1. H2 consumption was recorded by a TCD detector and calibrated using a standard CuO reference sample. In situ DRIFTS spectra were investigated on the Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Nicolet 6700) equipped with an MCT detector. The total flow rate was 100 mL·min−1. The samples were pretreated at 350 °C in N2 flow for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed species and cooled down to 250 °C. Then, a gas mixture NH3/N2 purged in and stopped until NH3 reached saturation. O2 was purged, and the spectra were collected at 0, 1, 3, 5, 10, 20 and 30 min, respectively. For NH3 adsorption experiments, the total flow rate was 100 mL·min−1. All spectra presented were collected by deducting the background spectra recorded during the sample exposing to pure N2 at the same temperature. The samples were first exposed to 500 ppm NH3 and then purged with N2 flow to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. The spectra were obtained at 100, 150, 200, 250, 300 and 350 °C, respectively. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The catalytic activity tests of NH3-SCO reactions were studied in a fixed-bed reactor (i.d., 6 mm). The composition of feed gas contained NH3 (400 ppm), O2 (10 vol. %), H2O (3.3 vol. %, if need), SO2 (100 ppm, if need) as well as balance N2 and passed through the catalyst bed with 100 mg catalyst. The total flow rate was 500 mL·min−1 with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of approximately 300,000 mL·g−1 h−1. The activity measurements were tested at 200 ˜ 400 °C under atmospheric pressure. The concentrations of inlet and outlet gases were continuously monitored with an IR spectrometer (Multi Gas 2030HS, MKS). The NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated from the inlet and outlet gases concentration according to the following Eqs. (1)–(2): (1) N H 3 conversion % = [ N H 3 ] in − [ N H 3 ] out [ N H 3 ] in * 100 (2) N 2 selectivity % = 1 − 2 * [ N 2 O ] out + [ N O 2 ] out + NO out [ N H 3 ] in − [ N H 3 ] out * 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological and physicochemical properties The SEM images (Fig. 1 ) present the morphological structure of H−CHA and CuOx/CHA catalysts. It can be seen that the samples still remain the original cubic crystal shape after the loadings of copper. The copper dispersion of CuOx/CHA catalysts were investigated by the EDS mapping images. As shown in Fig. S1, some highly dispersed copper species particles (pink dots) were obtained on the supports surface after the copper impregnation. The elemental analysis of the CuOx/CHA catalysts was obtained by ICP-OES and the amounts of Cu, Si, Al and P were summarized in Table 1 . The Cu species contents of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 and CuOx/H-SAPO-34 were 7.34 wt.% and 7.42 wt.%, respectively. This result indicates the active components of CuOx/CHA were similar to each other. N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted to obtain the BET surface area and pore properties of catalysts. As shown in Fig. S2, the N2 adsorption isotherms expressed that CuOx/CHA catalysts had the similar microporous structure with CHA supports. The introduction of copper on H-SSZ-13 and H-SAPO-34 supports did not lead to microporous structural damages. Table 1 shows that BET surface area of the supported catalysts is lower than that of the bare supports. It has two reasons. One is the formation of copper oxide clusters on the surface, which makes it difficult for N2 to be adsorbed on the inner walls of the CHA supports. The other one is the structural change in both samples which will be discussed below. Fig. 2 A shows the XRD results of supports and supported catalysts. Though there was some decrease in crystallinity, the supported catalysts still maintained the typical pattern of the microporous chabazite (CHA) structure, indicating the loadings of copper have not damaged the framework of CHA zeolites. Notably, CuOx/H-SSZ-13 catalyst showed an insignificant decrease in crystallinity compared to CuOx/H-SAPO-34, indicating H-SSZ-13 had better structural stability than H-SAPO-34 after Cu impregnation process. The typical diffraction peaks at 2θ = 35.3° and 38.5° assigned to cubic phase CuO (JCPDS 44–706) were observed in both CuOx/CHA samples. No Cu2O diffraction peaks were observed in both catalysts, which indicates Cu2O was undetectable. The solid-state NMR experiments were conducted to further examine the impact of Cu loading on the supports. Fig. S3 shows the 27Al NMR and 28Si NMR spectra of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 and H/SSZ-13. The 27Al NMR spectra (Fig. S3 (A)) has two peaks around 62 and 3 ppm, which can be assigned to framework, tetrahedral Al and extra-framework, octahedral Al, respectively [23]. The significant intensity difference between two peaks indicates that most Al atoms stay in the framework of both samples. Fig. S3 (B) shows the 28Si NMR spectra. The peaks at -110, -104 and -98 ppm were ascribed to Si (4Si, 0Al), Si (3Si, 1Al) and Si (2Si, 2Al), respectively [24]. There was little difference between CuOx/H-SSZ-13 and H-SSZ-13 samples in 27Al NMR and 28Si NMR spectra, which indicated the copper impregnation causes little structure damage on H-SSZ-13. The 27Al NMR, 28Si NMR and 31P NMR spectra for CuOx/H-SAPO-34 and H-SAPO-34 are shown in Fig. S4. As we can see from Fig. S4 (A), the peaks at 47, 19 and -6 ppm were assigned to tetrahedral Al (framework), pentcoordinated Al (extra-framework) and octahedral Al (extra-framework), repectively [25]. The 28Si NMR spectra (Fig. S4 (B)) contains three peaks around -108, -94 and -89 ppm, which can be ascribed Si (4Si, 0Al), Si (1Si, 3Al) and Si (0Si, 4Al), respectively. The 31P NMR spectra (Fig. S4 (C)) contains two peaks around -26 and -15 ppm, which can be assigned to framework P and extra-framework P, respectively [26]. Similarly, the peak intensity of H-SAPO-34 support had minor change after Cu impregnation. These observations showed that the structure of CuOx/CHA catalysts maintained intact. To confirm the chemical states of the copper species on the surface, XPS results of Cu 2p are revealed in Fig. 2B. It is shown that two main peaks with binding energies at about 930.0 ˜ 940.0 eV and 950.0 ˜ 960.0 eV were attributed to the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively. According to previous research, the Cu 2p3/2 peak at 936.0 eV and the satellite peak around 940.0 ˜ 948.0 eV indicated that copper species partly existed as CuO on the surface. While the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy at 933.7 eV was assigned to the reduced copper species (Cu2O) coexisting [27]. In combination with the XRD results, it can be known that CuO and Cu2O were coexisted in CuOx/CHA catalysts surface. To further determine the coordination environments of copper species in CuOx/CHA catalysts, EPR spectra were collected and shown Fig. S5. As we know, only isolated Cu2+ ions which has an unpaired electron are EPR active [28]. It is clear that isolated Cu2+ ions existed in both two catalysts. Besides, CuOx/H-SAPO-34 showed stronger signal intensity, which means CuOx/H-SAPO-34 had more isolated Cu2+ ions compared with CuOx/H-SSZ-13. 3.2 NH3-SCO catalytic activity The NH3 oxidation activity was examined using the feed gas containing 400 ppm NH3, 10 vol.% O2 in balance N2 at the WHSV of 300,000 mL·g−1 h−1 from 200 to 400 °C. It was clear that the support of H-SSZ-13 and H-SAPO-34 exhibited poor performance for ammonia oxidation below 400 °C (Fig. 3 A). The introduction of copper onto these supports resulted in a dramatic increase of NH3 oxidation activity. Furthermore, CuOx/H-SSZ-13 showed a much higher NH3 conversion than CuOx/H-SAPO-34. Notably, 94% NH3 conversion was obtained at 225 °C for CuOx/H-SSZ-13. In contrast, T90 (i.e., 90% NH3 conversion) of CuOx/H-SAPO-34 was over 300 °C. In addition, N2 selectivity results are shown in Fig. 3B, it is essential that both CuOx/CHA catalysts demonstrated much higher N2 selectivity than that of commercial 1% Pt/Al2O3. The effects of H2O over CuOx/CHA catalysts were evaluated and the results are shown in Fig. S6. At low temperatures, NH3 conversion of CuOx/CHA catalysts decreased due to the addition of H2O. However, good catalytic activity remained at high temperatures. The complete NH3 conversion temperatures shifted to higher temperatures when H2O existed. It was because of the water adsorption or condensation on the catalysts that resulted in partial blocking of the active sites [15]. Moreover, N2 selectivity was affected slightly by H2O for both CuOx/CHA catalysts. A further experiment was carried out at 325 °C to investigate the influence of H2O. 3.3 vol.% H2O was added to the feed at 100 min and then cut off at 600 min. As shown in Fig. 4 , NH3 was converted almost entirely during the initial dry condition. When H2O was added, NH3 conversion decreased to about 90% (CuOx/H-SSZ-13) and 20% (CuOx/H-SAPO-34), respectively. After the feed was switched back to the dry period, both NH3 conversions were recovered to the similar level of the initial dry condition. These experiments confirm that H2O in the feed has an adverse effect on the SCO performance. However, the deactivation of H2O appears to be reversible. Meanwhile, the preparation method also had an influence on the catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. S7, catalysts prepared by wet impregnation procedure (IM-CuOx/CHA) exhibited much higher catalytic activity than that by the ion-exchange procedure (IE-Cu2+/CHA). Copper species in IE-Cu2+/CHA mostly existed in the form of isolated Cu2+ ions as Su et al. proposed [26]. However, CuOx were generally regarded as active phases in the process of ammonia oxidation [29]. This result indicates that wet impregnation procedure is more suitable than the ion-exchange procedure for copper-based catalysts in the NH3-SCO reactions. Regardless of the preparation method, Cu(Cu2+ or CuOx)/SSZ-13 still perform higher NH3 conversion compared to Cu(Cu2+ or CuOx)/SAPO-34, demonstrating that H-SSZ-13 is more suitable than H-SAPO-34 for copper-based SCO catalysts. The stability of CuOx/CHA catalysts were evaluated by hydrothermal aging experiments. As shown in Fig. 5 , the hydrothermal aging treatment led to the activity loss of both CuOx/CHA catalysts, especially for CuOx/H-SAPO-34. After hydrothermal aging treatment, the NH3 conversion of CuOx/H-SAPO-34 is less than 50% over the whole temperature range. However, for CuOx/H-SSZ-13 the NH3 conversion at low temperatures only had a little loss and its T90 increased by about 25 ℃. This result showed that CuOx/H-SSZ-13 catalyst had better stability. In order to further show the excellent catalytic performance of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 catalyst, a summary of NH3-SCO conversion and selectivity under different catalysts and reaction conditions were summarized in Table S1. It can be seen that CuOx/H-SSZ-13 catalysts is quite comparable to noble-metal based catalysts, especially at low temperatures. In addition, CuOx/H-SSZ-13 showed more excellent catalytic performance than most transition-metal based catalysts and other zeolite-based catalysts. Therefore, CuOx/H-SSZ-13 can be regarded as one of the most promising catalysts in practical applications of ammonia oxidation process. 3.3 The acid properties of catalysts The adsorption and activation of NH3 play important roles in governing catalytic activities. Since NH3 adsorption on the surface is the first step in the NH3-SCO reactions, NH3-TPD experiments and in situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out to investigate the acidity of the supported catalysts. Fig. S8 shows that desorption of ammonia occurs from 150 °C up to high temperatures. The total acidity of catalysts was normalized to the surface area and shown in Table 2 . The supports H-SSZ-13 and H-SAPO-34 provided the most proportion of acidity over the CuOx/CHA catalysts. After the introduction of copper, the acidity of CuOx/CHA catalysts was promoted and more NH3 desorbed from CuOx/CHA catalysts at lower temperatures. This result suggests that copper could provide additional acid sites and enhance the NH3 adsorption at lower temperatures. A similar observation has been already reported by Li et.al and found that the deposited copper centers may act as Lewis acid sites [30]. The CuOx/H-SAPO-34 showed the lower acidity and less acidity increment compared to the CuOx/H-SSZ-13, indicating CuOx/H-SSZ-13 owned more abundant acid sites for NH3 adsorption. Moreover, the amount of desorption ammonia from CuOx/H-SSZ-13 at low temperatures was much greater than that of CuOx/H-SAPO-34, which means CuOx/H-SSZ-13 had an advantage in providing suitable reaction conditions at low temperatures. The DRIFTS spectra of NH3 adsorption over CuOx/CHA catalysts at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 6 . Several bands were observed after CuOx/H-SSZ-13 was treated with 500 ppm NH3 at 100 °C (Fig. 6A). The bands at 3346, 3272, 3217 and 3189 cm−1 could be attributed to the NH stretching vibration bands of NH3 [31]. The bands at 1618, 1270 and 1180 cm−1 were ascribed to symmetric and asymmetric deformation modes of NH3 coordinated on Lewis acid sites. The weak band at 1450 cm−1 was ascribed to the bending vibration of NH4 + species on the Brønsted acid sites [32,33]. The intensities of the bands at 1618, 1270 and 1180 cm−1 noticeably decreased with increasing temperature from the beginning. When the temperature increased to 350 °C, the bands at 1618 and 1180 cm−1 (adsorbed NH3 on Lewis acid sites) almost disappeared while the band at 1450 cm−1 (adsorbed NH4 + on Brønsted acid sites) still retained, indicating the ammonia absorbed on Brønsted acid sites were more stable. Except for changes of bands bound up with NH3, some intermediates were also observed. The band at 1565 cm−1 corresponded to –NH2 species and the band at 1415 cm−1 corresponded to –NH species were two central intermediates during the ammonia oxidation process [34,35]. With the increase of temperature, the peak intensity of –NH2 decreased while the peak intensity of –NH increased, revealing that –NH2 species could further be dissociated into –NH in the process of heating. The adsorbed NH3 species of CuOx/H-SAPO-34 (Fig. 6B) were similar to that of CuOx/H-SSZ-13. After the catalysts were treated with 500 ppm NH3 at 100 °C, several bands in the NH stretching region were found at 3350, 3280, 3320 and 3187 cm−1. The strong peaks at 1620, 1286 and 1215 cm−1 could be attributed to symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of NH3 coordinately linked to Lewis acid sites. Another band at 1470 cm−1 was attributed to the bending vibration of NH4 + species bonded to Brønsted acid sites. Due to the NH3 desorption, the intensities of the bands at 1620, 1286 and 1215 cm−1 decreased from the outset. While the strength of the peak at 1470 cm−1 decreased when the temperature was elevated to 250 ℃. This result shows that NH3 bonded on Brønsted acid sites was more stable, which was in good consistent with that of CuOx/H-SSZ-13. However, there were no intermediates observed on the CuOx/H-SAPO-34. Based on the results above, it could be found that CuOx/CHA catalysts contained both Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites. Upon heating, coordinated NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites were more easily to desorb than the coordinated NH3 on the Brønsted acid sites for CuOx/CHA catalysts. Different from CuOx/H-SAPO-34, CuOx/H-SSZ-13 could activate the absorbed NH3 to –NH2 intermediates by abstracting hydrogen and further dehydrogenated to form –NH species as the temperature increased. 3.4 The redox properties of catalysts H2-TPR experiments were carried out to elucidate the redox properties presented in CuOx/CHA catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7 A, there should to be three peaks for both catalysts. It is well known that different copper species would have different redox properties. The first peak α (˜ 270 °C) was due to the reduction of surface CuO to Cu0. The second peak β (˜ 310 °C) was related to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ ions to Cu+ ions. The third peak γ (above 800 °C) was due to the reduction of Cu+ to Cu0 [36,37] The H2 consumption amount and the peak temperatures were summarized in Table 2. For each reduction process, the reduction temperature of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 was lower than that of CuOx/H-SAPO-34, indicating that CuOx/H-SSZ-13 showed better low-temperature reducibility. Besides, the ratio of β/(α + β) for CuOx/H-SAPO-34 (76.0%) was higher than CuOx/H-SSZ-13 (57.6%). This result demonstrated that CuOx/H-SAPO-34 are more abundant in isolated Cu2+ ions, which was consistent with the EPR results. To further explain the difference of redox properties between CuOx/CHA catalysts, we use the initial H2 consumption rate to evaluate reducibility of catalysts. The initial H2 consumption rate was calculated according to the H2 amount consumed per second per mole of copper. The rate represents the initial 25% area of the first reduction peak where no phase transformation of the samples occurs [38]. Fig. 7B shows that the initial H2 consumption rate versus inverse temperature of the CuOx/CHA catalysts. It is obvious that the initial H2 consumption rate of CuOx/H-/SSZ-13 was much higher than that of CuOx/H-SAPO-34. This tendency in low-temperature reducibility was consistent with their catalytic performance sequence shown above. We can easily infer that stronger redox property results in a lower temperature for complete ammonia conversion over CuOx/H-SSZ-13. 3.5 In situ DRIFTS results In situ DRIFTS spectra of O2 interacted with pre-adsorbed NH3 species over CuOx/CHA catalysts at 250 °C were presented in Fig. 8 . From Fig. 8A, after CuOx/H-SSZ-13 was saturated with NH3 at 250 °C, the peaks related to NH3 were observed at 3336, 3270, 3218, 3180, 1616, 1464, 1270 and 1187 cm−1. The bands at 1616, 1270 and 1187 cm−1 were due to the asymmetric and symmetric deformation of NH3 coordinately bonded to Lewis acid sites. The peaks at 1464 cm−1 could be assigned to the NH4 + species adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites. After O2 inlet, the peak intensities of NH3 bonded on Lewis acid sites gradually decreased due to the activation of NH3. Besides, bands corresponding to –NH2 (1564 cm−1) and –NH (1390 cm−1) were observed during the reactions. The peak intensity of –NH increased with a decrease in the intensity of –NH2, suggesting –NH2 could further dissociate into –NH in the O2 atmosphere [39]. Fig. 8B shows the results of the same experiments performed on CuOx/H-SAPO-34. Bands related to Brønsted acid sites (1465 cm−1) and Lewis acid sites (1620 and 1277 cm−1) were confirmed. The bands of NH3 coordinated on Lewis acid sites decreased in the presence of O2. The intermediate species –NH2 band (1560 cm−1) appeared to increase gradually after experiment beginning. It was noted that no –NH species were observed over CuOx/H-SAPO-34. This result reveals the redox property of CuOx/H-SAPO-34 was not strong enough to further dehydrogenate –NH2 into –NH species, which was in good agreement with H2-TPR experiments. According to the acidic properties discussed above, NH4 + bonded to Brønsted acid sites was more stable. The integrated peak areas of 1616/1620 cm−1 in the DRIFTS spectra at different reaction times were calculated to obtain the reaction rate of these catalysts’ Lewis acidity. As shown in Fig. S9, when the reaction went on, both CuOx/CHA catalysts’ reaction rate increased quickly and became smooth slowly. The difference was the reaction rate of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 was much faster than that of CuOx/H-SAPO-34 in the first 5 min. This result indicates that the reactions between O2 and NH3 (coordinately linked to Lewis acid sites) of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 take place at a faster rate. 3.6 The effect of SO2 We further studied the effects of SO2 on the catalytic performance of CuOx/CHA catalysts. When 100 ppm SO2 was introduced to the inlet gases, NH3 conversion gradually decreased with time and remained only approximately 40% NH3 conversion at 325 °C. When SO2 was absent from the reaction gas, NH3 conversion could be recovered more than 90% catalytic activity, indicating that the deactivation was mostly reversible (Fig. 9 A). The similar tendency of NH3 conversion was obtained by adding H2O and SO2 together to the steam. To determine the sulfate species on the poisoned catalysts, SO2-TPD and NH3+SO2-TPD experiments were performed. In Fig. 9B, there were two major SO2 desorption peaks observed at 120 °C and 700 °C. The lower temperature peak could be ascribed to weakly adsorbed SO2 and the higher temperature peak could be attributed to the decomposition of strongly combined SO4 2− species such as CuSO4 whose decomposition temperature is above 600 °C [40]. NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 could decompose from the surface when the temperature is above 350 °C. There were small amounts of strongly combined SO4 2− species which generated on the catalysts could not decompose at 325 °C. Due to this reason, there was still parts of catalytic activity loss even if SO2 removal from the inlet gases. SO2+NH3-TPD experiments were performed to explain the reaction between catalysts and SO2. Fig. S10 showed the TPD results of catalysts saturated by NH3 directly and catalysts treated by SO2 firstly and then purged by NH3. The acidity of both CuOx/CHA catalysts was increased (Table S2), which could be attributed to the combination between catalysts and SO2. It can be inferred that the formation of sulfur species raised the acid sites on the surface. The location of SO2 desorption peaks over CuOx/H-SAPO-34 was quite similar to the results of SO2-TPD (Fig. 10 ). However, there was a hysteresis of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 and both SO2 desorption peaks were shifted in the direction of higher temperatures (almost 300 °C). This phenomenon indicates that SO2 anchored more stable on the CuOx/H-SSZ-13. 4 Conclusion We compared two CuOx/CHA catalysts by investigating their physicochemical properties and catalytic performance for NH3-SCO reactions. CuOx/H-SSZ-13 showed better SCO activity and N2 selectivity (94% NH3 conversion at 225 °C with 93% N2 selectivity) than CuOx/H-SAPO-34 under both dry and wet atmosphere. The reasons for different catalytic performance between CuOx/CHA catalysts were discussed as well. The acid sites of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 were more plentiful than those of CuOx/H-SAPO-34, which were beneficial for NH3 adsorption. Stronger redox properties enabled CuOx/H-SSZ-13 to have a better NH3-SCO catalytic activity at low temperatures. In situ DRIFTS spectra showed CuOx/H-SSZ-13 produced more intermediate species during the NH3-SCO reactions. As for the effect of SO2 in the steam, SO2 did inhibit the NH3-SCO reactions, but most of NH3 conversions recovered after SO2 removal. The SO2 poisoning mechanism could be divided into reversible and irreversible parts. Reversible deactivation was due to the formation of NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 species which may cover the active sites. However, NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 could decompose when temperature above 350 ℃. In the power station, the temperature window is above 350 ℃ as well, which means SO2 and H2O would have little effect on the catalytic performance of CuOx/CHA catalysts. A small amount of strongly combined sulfates such as CuSO4 potentially contributed to the irreversible deactivation. To sum up, it should be highlighted that CuOx/CHA, especially CuOx/H-SSZ-13, are promising catalysts for environmental and efficient oxidation of NH3. coredata.dc:description: In this work, CuOx/Chabazite(CHA, SSZ-13, SAPO-34 etc) catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method for ammonia selective catalytic oxidation. CuOx/H-SSZ-13 exhibited superior NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity compared with CuOx/H-SAPO-34 below 300 °C under both dry and wet conditions. The better low-temperature activity of CuOx/H-SSZ-13 was due to its greater NH3 adsorption and activation capacity. DRIFTS results showed that –NH2 and –NH radicals can be observed on the spectra of CuOx/H-SSZ-13, whereas, only –NH2 radicals were obtained on the spectra of CuOx/H-SAPO-34. CuOx (including CuO and Cu2O) were determined as active phases of the catalysts using XRD and XPS results. The catalytic performance of CuOx/CHA catalysts was reversibly suppressed in the presence of H2O and SO2 regarding the formation of NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 on the catalysts surface. Furthermore, CuSO4 was also formed and could not decompose until 700 °C. However, it showed less influence on the catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Comparison of NH3-SCO performance over CuOx/H-SSZ-13 and CuOx/H-SAPO-34 catalysts
